revision.comment: Rescuing 3 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{Coord|60|N|100|E|type:country|display=title}}
[[File:Russian Geologic Regions Detailed.svg|300px|thumbnail|right|A topographic map of Russia with regions labeled.]]
The '''geology of Russia''', the world's largest country, which extends over much of northern [[Eurasia]], consists of several stable [[craton]]s and [[sedimentary]] [[Platform (geology)|platform]]s bounded by [[orogen]]ic [[mountain range|(mountain) belt]]s.
The European part of [[Russia]] is on the [[East European craton]], at the heart of which is a complex of [[igneous]] and [[metamorphic rock]]s dating back to the [[Precambrian]]. The craton is bounded on the east by the long tract of compressed and highly deformed rock that constitutes the Ural [[orogen]]. The area between the [[Ural Mountains]] and the [[Yenisei River]] is the young [[West Siberian Plain]]. East of the Yenisei River is the ancient [[Central Siberian Plateau]], extending to the [[Lena River]]. East of the Lena River there is the Verhoyansk-Chukotka collision zone, stretching to the [[Chukchi Peninsula]].
The orogens within Russia belong to the [[Baltic Shield]], the [[Timanide Orogen|Timanides]], the Urals, the [[Altai Mountains]], the Ural-Mongolian [[Paleozoic|epipaleozoic]] orogen and the northwestern part of the Pacific orogeny. The country's highest mountains, the [[Caucasus Mountains|Caucasus]], are confined to younger orogens.
==East European craton== {{see also|White Sea Rift System}} The European part of Russia lies on the East European platform, a region up to {{convert|3000|km|mi}} wide covered by more than {{convert|3|km|mi}} of [[metasediment|metamorphosed sediments]] dating back to the [[Riphean stage]] (middle to late [[Proterozoic]], from 1,400 to 800 million years ago). These sediments lie on the [[East European craton]], a remnant of [[Precambrian]] continental [[crust (geology)|crust]] composed of [[magmatic rock|magmatic]] and metamorphic rocks.<ref name="Bogdanova 2007">{{cite journal|last=Bogdanova|first=S.V.|author2=Bingen, B. |author3=Gorbatschev, R. |author4=Kheraskova, T.N. |author5=Kozlov, V.I. |author6=Puchkov, V.N. |author7= Volozh, Yu.A. |title=The East European Craton (Baltica) before and during the assembly of Rodinia|journal=Precambrian Research|date=31 December 2007|volume=160|issue=1–2|pages=23–45|doi=10.1016/j.precamres.2007.04.024|bibcode=2008PreR..160...23B}}</ref> The East European craton itself was created between 2.0 and 1.7 [[1000000000 (number)|billion]] years ago when the [[microcontinent]]s of [[Baltic Shield|Fennoscandia]], [[Sarmatian craton|Sarmatia]] and [[Volgo-Uralia]] collided.<ref name="Pesonen 2003">{{cite journal|last=Pesonen|first=L.J.|author2=Elming, S.-Å. |author3=Mertanen, S. |author4=Pisarevsky, S. |author5=D'Agrella-Filho, M.S. |author6=Meert, J.G. |author7=Schmidt, P.W. |author8=Abrahamsen, N. |author9= Bylund, G. |title=Palaeomagnetic configuration of continents during the Proterozoic|journal=Tectonophysics|date=1 November 2003|volume=375|issue=1–4|pages=289–324|doi=10.1016/S0040-1951(03)00343-3|bibcode=2003Tectp.375..289P}}</ref>
===Timan Ridge=== {{main|Timanide Orogen}} The [[Timan Ridge]] ({{lang-ru|Тиманский кряж}} – ''Timansky Kryazh'') lies west of the Northern Ural mountains. It [[strike (geology)|strike]]s northwest–southeast, extending from the settlement of [[Troitsko-Pechorsk]] to the [[Kanin Peninsula]]. This ridge can be correlated with [[outcrop]]s on the [[Varanger Peninsula]] which together form the Timan-Varanger belt.<ref name="Olovyanishnikov 2000">{{cite journal|last=Olovyanishnikov|first=Vsevolod G.|author2=David Roberts |author3=Anna Siedlecka |title=Tectonics and Sedimentation of the Meso- to Neoproterozoic Timan-Varanger Belt along the Northeastern Margin of Baltica|journal=Polarforschung|year=2000|volume=68|pages=267–274|url=http://epic.awi.de/28442/1/Polarforsch1998_33.pdf|accessdate=20 October 2012}}</ref> The Timan-Varanger belt consists of [[Neoproterozoic]] (late Precambrian) sediments that were metamorphosed and deformed during the Timanian (or Baikalian) orogeny, a late Neoproterozoic mountain-building event coincident with the [[Cadomian orogeny]] in western Europe.<ref name="Olovyanishnikov 2000" />
===Timan-Pechora Basin=== {{main|Timan-Pechora Basin}} The [[Timan-Pechora Basin]] is a [[sedimentary]] basin that lies between the Timan Ridge and the Urals foreland basin. The basin extends into the southern part of the [[Barents sea]] and includes [[Kolguyev Island]]. It is covered by {{convert|6|to|12|km|mi}} of sediments that were deposited during a series of marine [[Marine regression|regression]] and [[Marine transgression|transgression]] events from the [[Proterozoic]] to the [[Cenozoic]]. The eastern basin was deformed when the Ural mountains were formed.<ref name="Clarke 1994">{{cite journal|last=Clarke|first=James W.|title=The Timan-Pechora Oil-Gas Basin: A Geological Review|journal=International Geology Review|date=1 January 1994|volume=36|issue=1|pages=3–14|doi=10.1080/00206819409465444 }}</ref> The Basin is further divided into the Izhma-Pechora basin, Pechora-Kolva basin, Khoreiver basin and the Northern Pre-Urals.<ref name="Blackbourn map">{{cite web|title=Timan-Pechora hydrocarbon region|url=http://www.blackbourn.co.uk/databases/hydrocarbon-province-maps/timan.pdf|publisher=Blackbourn|accessdate=20 October 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130603202435/http://www.blackbourn.co.uk/databases/hydrocarbon-province-maps/timan.pdf#|archive-date=2013-06-03|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
===Volgo-Uralian Block=== {{main|Volgo-Uralia}} The Volgo-Uralian Block is a basement of Archean craton covered by younger sediments,<ref>{{cite encyclopedia|title=Geology of Europe|last=Neubauer|first=Franz|volume=4|encyclopedia=Encyclopedia of Life Support Systems}}</ref> making up the eastern third of the East European Craton. This crystalline basement is made up of [[amphibolite]] to granulite [[facies]],<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Volgo-Uralia: a large piece of the global Archaean framework|last = Bogdanova|last2=Bibikova|last3=De Waele|last4=Postnikov|journal= Geophysical Research Abstracts |volume=9|year=2007|url=http://meetings.copernicus.org/www.cosis.net/abstracts/EGU2007/05510/EGU2007-J-05510.pdf|accessdate=19 February 2013}}</ref> mostly forming [[Dome (geology)|domes]]. [[Granitoid]]s deformed into gneisses are contained. The sedimentary rocks covering these domes are of Neoproterozoic to Phanerozoic age.<ref>{{cite journal|title = Volgo-Uralia: The First U-Pb, Lu-Hf and Sm-Nd Isotopic Evidence of Preserves Paleoarchean Crust|last=Bogdanova|first=Svetlana|last2=De Waele|first2=Bert|last3=Bibikova|first3=Elena|last4=Belousova|first4=Elena|last5=Postnikov|first5=Alexander|last6=Fedotova|first6=Anna|last7=Popova|first7=Lubov|journal=American Journal of Science|volume=310|date=December 2010|pages=1345–1383|url=http://www.ajsonline.org/content/310/10/1345.full.pdf|accessdate=19 February 2013|issue=10|doi=10.2475/10.2010.06|bibcode=2010AmJS..310.1345B}}</ref>
==Caucasus Mountains== {{main|Caucasus Mountains#Geology}}
The [[Arabian plate]] has been [[Convergent boundary|converging]] towards the East European craton at 29 mm/yr; however, subduction has not occurred because of the presence of three blocks separating the plate and craton.<ref name="Triep1995">{{cite journal|title=Active thrust front of the Greater Caucasus |last=Triep |last2=Abers |first2=G. A. |last3=Lerner-Lam |first3=A. L. |last4=Mishatkin |first4=V. |last5=Zakharchenko |first5=N. |last6=Starovoit |first6=O. |journal=Journal of Geophysical Research |volume=100 |pages=4011–4033 |date=10 March 1995 |url=http://people.bu.edu/abers/papers/Triep++94JB02597.pdf |accessdate=21 February 2013 |doi=10.1029/94JB02597 |bibcode=1995JGR...100.4011T |first1=E. G. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110622025917/http://people.bu.edu/abers/papers/Triep++94JB02597.pdf |archivedate=22 June 2011 |df= }}</ref> The convergence has forced up the Caucasus Mountains. The core of the mountains is mostly composed of [[metasediment]]ary Paleozoic rocks.<ref name = "Ruppel1990">{{cite journal|title = Regional compensation of the Greater Caucasus mountains based on an analysis of Bouguer gravity data|last=Ruppel|last2=McNutt|journal=Earth and Planetary Science Letters|volume=98|issue=3–4|date=June 1990|pages=360–379|doi=10.1016/0012-821X(90)90037-X|bibcode=1990E&PSL..98..360R}}</ref>
Deformation outside the core has mostly taken place on the southern slopes of the mountains; however, there is some deformation on the North slopes. This deformation is differentiated on the north slopes from East to West.<ref name = "Philip1989">{{cite journal|title=The Caucasus |last=Philip |last2=Cisternas |last3=Gvishiani |last4=Gorshkov |journal=Tectonophysics |volume=161 |issue=1–2 |date=1 April 1989|pages=1–21|doi=10.1016/0040-1951(89)90297-7|bibcode = 1989Tectp.161....1P }}</ref> In the west, some thrusting to the North of the Crest has taken place into the [[Kuban Basin]].<ref name="Philip1989"/> When the thrusting die out the north slopes of the central Greater Caucasus form a basement uplift,<ref name = "Ruppel1990"/> forming a [[monocline]] dipping North. [[Dagestan]] to the Eastern end of the range is the where most thrusting to the North occurs and has formed a folded zone of sediments, overlying some of the [[Terek Basin]].<ref name="Philip1989"/>
==Caspian Basin== The [[Caspian Sea|Caspian Basin]] is a system of [[basin (geology)|basin]]s and platforms. It is divided into smaller basins, in the North, the North Caspian Basin. The north is a basin at the edge of the cratons to the north. It is composed of Paleozoic [[carbonate]] platforms.<ref name="Talwani1998">{{cite web|title= Geology and Petroleum Potential of Central Asia|last= Talwani|first= Manik|last2= Belopolsky|first2= Andrei|last3= Berry|first3= Dianne|publisher= Rice University|year= 1998|url= http://www.bakerinstitute.org/publications/geology-and-petroleum-potential-of-the-caspian-sea-region|accessdate= 19 February 2013|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20130504092359/http://bakerinstitute.org/publications/geology-and-petroleum-potential-of-the-caspian-sea-region#|archive-date= 2013-05-04|dead-url= yes|df= }}</ref> The North Basin overlies a basement of European Craton.<ref name="Knapp2004">{{cite journal|title=Crustal-scalestructure of the South Caspian Basin revealed by deep seismic reflection profiling |last=Knapp |first=Camelia |last2=knapp |first2=James |last3=Connor |first3=John |journal=[[Marine and Petroleum Geology]] |volume=21 |issue=8 |year=2004 |pages=1073–1081 |url=http://rainier.seis.sc.edu/camelia/Pubs/MPG-Knapp%20et%20al%2004.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060915075947/http://rainier.seis.sc.edu/camelia/Pubs/MPG-Knapp%20et%20al%2004.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=15 September 2006 |accessdate=19 February 2013 |doi=10.1016/j.marpetgeo.2003.04.002 }}</ref> Mesozoic and Tertiary sediments deposited by a variety of methods have covered the continental crust.<ref name="Einsele1997"> {{cite journal |title=Terrestrial Sediment yield and the lifetimes of reservoirs, lakes and larger basins |last=Einsele |last2=Hinderer |first2=M. |journal=Geol Rundsch |volume=86 |issue=2 |year=1997 |pages=288–310 |url=http://enviro.lclark.edu:8002/rid=1205349457228_10882556_995/Hinderer1997.pdf |accessdate=19 February 2013 |doi=10.1007/s005310050141 |first1=G. |bibcode=1997GeoRu..86..288E }}{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} </ref>
==Ural orogen== {{main|Uralian orogeny|Ural Mountains#Geology}} The [[Ural Mountains]], a 2,500 kilometre (1,600 mi) long mountain chain that runs north-south at approximately 60° E longitude, formed in the [[Ural orogeny]], a long series of mountain-building events occurring at the eastern margin of what is now the East European [[craton]] in association with its collision with another microcontinent (the Kazakhstania [[terrane]]) to the east.<ref name="Hetzel 2002">{{cite journal|last=Hetzel|first=R.|author2=J., Glodny|title=A crustal-scale, orogen-parallel strike-slip fault in the Middle Urals: age, magnitude of displacement, and geodynamic significance|journal=International Journal of Earth Sciences|date=28 February 2002|volume=91|issue=2|pages=231–245|doi=10.1007/s005310100208|url=http://www.uni-ms.de/GeoPalaeontologie/Geologie/Endogen/pdf/Hetzel_Glodny%202002.pdf|accessdate=15 October 2012|bibcode=2002IJEaS..91..231H|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140203130908/http://www.uni-ms.de/GeoPalaeontologie/Geologie/Endogen/pdf/Hetzel_Glodny%202002.pdf#|archive-date=2014-02-03|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref name="Cocks Torsvik 2006" /> The first phase of orogenic development occurred in the late [[Devonian]] and early [[Carboniferous]], when [[volcanic arc|volcanic]] [[island arc]]s developed and accreted to the continental margin. During the subsequent collision stage, extensive [[fold (geology)|fold]]ing, [[fault (geology)|fault]]ing, and [[metamorphism]] occurred.<ref name="Hetzel 2002"/> Deformation during the collision stage propagated from the south northwards, reaching the [[Pay-Khoy|Pay-Khoy mountains]] during the [[Jurassic]].<ref name="Puchkov 2002">{{cite journal|last=Puchkov|first=V.|title=Paleozoic evolution of the east European continental margin involved in the Uralide orogeny|journal=Geophysical Monograph Series| year=2002| volume=132| pages=9–31|doi=10.1029/132GM02| url=http://www.agu.org/books/gm/v132/132GM02/132GM02.shtml|accessdate=15 October 2012| bibcode=2002GMS...132....9P|series=Geophysical Monograph Series|isbn=0-87590-991-4}}</ref> The strong influence of [[strike-slip]] movements during the orogeny caused the unusual straightness of the mountain chain.<ref name="Cocks Torsvik 2006" />
==West Siberian basin== {{main|West Siberian petroleum basin}} [[File:Západní Sibiř.png|thumb|right|Western Siberian plain on a satellite map of [[North Asia]].]] The West Siberian basin lies between the Ural mountains and the Siberian craton to its east. It corresponds to the geographic region of the [[West Siberian plain]]. Deposition in rift valleys resulting from prolonged subsidence of the Triassic Koltogor-Urengoy graben in an intra-cratonic sag basin<ref name=EIAJune2013>{{cite web|title=Technically Recoverable Shale Oil and Shale Gas Resources: An Assessment of 137 Shale Formations in 41 Countries Outside the United States|url=http://www.eia.gov/analysis/studies/worldshalegas/pdf/fullreport.pdf|publisher=U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA)|accessdate=June 11, 2013|format=PDF|date=June 2013}}</ref> beginning in the [[Jurassic]] has resulted in a thick 'basin fill' of sedimentary deposits ranging from Jurassic to [[Cenozoic]] in age.<ref name=Cocks2007/> There are two major north-south trending [[rift (geology)|rift]] structures of Triassic age buried beneath the basin fill: the [[Urengoy rift|Urengoy]] and the [[Khudosey rift]]. These rifts are mainly filled with Lower Triassic basic volcanic rocks.<ref name="Ulmishek 2003"/>
The West Siberian basin and its offshore portions in the [[Kara Sea|south Kara sea]] are the largest oil province in the world. It has an area of {{convert|2200000|km2|mi2}} and the [[USGS]] estimates oil and gas [[oil reserve|reserve]]s of 360 billion [[barrel (unit)|barrel]]s of oil equivalent in the basin.<ref name="Ulmishek 2003">{{cite journal|last=Ulmishek|first=Gregory F.|title=Petroleum Geology and Resources of the West Siberian Basin, Russia|journal=U.S. Geological Survey Bulletin|year=2003|issue=2201–G|page=49|url=http://pubs.usgs.gov/bul/2201/G/B2201-G.pdf|accessdate=14 October 2012}}</ref><ref name="Schenk 2008">{{cite web|last=Schenk|first=Christopher J.|title=Assessment of Undiscovered Oil and Gas Resources of the West Siberian Basin Province, Russia, 2008|url=http://pubs.usgs.gov/fs/2008/3064/pdf/FS08-3064_508.pdf|publisher=USGS|accessdate=14 October 2012}}</ref>
==Yenisey fold belt== {{Main|Yenisey Fold Belt}} Dividing the Siberian craton from the West Siberian basin is the Yenisey fold belt, which extends about {{convert|700|km|mi}},<ref name = "Vernikovsky 2003">{{cite journal|title = Neoproterozoic accertionary and collisional events on the western margin of the Siberian craton|last = Vernikovsky|first = Valery|last2 = Vernikovsky|first2 = A.E.|last3 = Kotov|first3 = A.B.|last4 = Sal'nikova|first4 = E.B.|last5 = Kovach|first5 = V.P.|journal = Tectonophysics|volume = 375|pages = 147–168|year = 2003|doi=10.1016/S0040-1951(03)00337-8|bibcode=2003Tectp.375..147V}}</ref> with NW-SE strike. This belt is divided into northern and southern regions by the Angara fault which has left slip.<ref name = "Vernikovsky 2004">{{cite journal|title = Neoproterozoic Orogeny along the margins of Siberia|last = Vernikovsky|first1 = V.A.|last2 = Vernikovskaya|first2 = A.E.|last3 = Pease|first3 = V.L.|last4 = Gee|first4 = D.G.|journal = The Neoproterozoic Timanide Orogen of Eastern Baltica|volume = 30|pages = 233–248|year = 2004|doi=10.1144/gsl.mem.2004.030.01.18}}</ref> Much of the rock was formed by Neoprotozoic [[Accretion (geology)|accretion]].<ref name = "Vernikovsky 2003"/>
North of the fault, the area is made up of [[Tectonostratigraphy|thrust sheets]]<ref name = "Vernikovsky 2004"/> divided into three primarily Neoproterozoic terranes, the East Angara, Central Angara and the Isakov.<ref name = "Vernikovsky 2003"/> Each one overrides another, and volcanism is generally limited to the Central and Isakov terranes.<ref name = Linnemann2007>{{cite book|title = The Evolution of the Rheic Ocean|last = Linnemann|first = Ulf|publisher = GSA|year = 2007|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=-dj9C_VvmDwC|accessdate = 10 February 2013|isbn = 9780813724232}}</ref> South of the fault are the Predivinsk terrane, made of island arc accretion, and the Angara-Kan micro-craton, which is sometimes considered separate from the fold belt.<ref name = Rundqvist1997>{{cite book|chapter=Yenisey fold belt|last = Khiltova|last2 = Pleskach|title = Precambrian Ore Deposits of the East European and Siberian Cratons|editor = Rundqvist|editor2 = Gillen|year = 1997|publisher = Elsevier Science|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=gQnOVViJUOwC|accessdate = 10 February 2013|isbn = 9780080539430}}</ref>
==Siberian craton== [[File:Siberian craton location.jpg|thumb|right|Central Siberian Plateau's location in [[Asia]].]]
The Siberian craton (or West-Siberian craton) coincides with the [[Central Siberian Plateau|Central Siberian plateau]] that lies between the [[Yenisei River|Yenisei]] and [[Lena River|Lena]] rivers. In the west it borders the West Siberian basin. The Yenisei-Katanga trough lies in the north. In the south lies the Central Asian fold belt, the [[Baikal Rift Zone|Baikal rift]] and the Mongol-Okhotsk fold belt. The eastern border is the Verkhoyansk-Kolyma orogenic system.<ref name="Pavlenkova 2002">{{cite journal|last=Pavlenkova|first=G.A|author2=Priestley, K |author3=Cipar, J |title=2D model of the crust and uppermost mantle along rift profile, Siberian craton|journal=Tectonophysics| date=31 August 2002| volume=355| issue=1–4|pages=171–186|doi=10.1016/S0040-1951(02)00140-3| bibcode=2002Tectp.355..171P}}</ref><ref name="Gusev 1987">{{cite journal|last=Gusev|first=G.S.|author2=Shpount, B.R.|title=Precambrian and Paleozoic rifting in northeastern Asia|journal=Tectonophysics| date=1 November 1987|volume=143| issue=1–3|pages=245–252| doi=10.1016/0040-1951(87)90094-1|bibcode = 1987Tectp.143..245G }}</ref>
The Siberian craton formed in the Precambrian and is largely covered by sedimentary and volcanic rocks of more recent age. Precambrian rocks are exposed in two distinct uplifts, the Anabar [[massif]] in the northeast and the Aldanian [[shield (geology)|shield]] in the southeast.<ref name=Cocks2007>{{cite journal |url=http://www.geodynamics.no/guest/siberia2007.pdf |title=Siberia, the wandering northern terrane, and its changing geography through the Palaeozoic |first=L. Robin M. |last=Cocks |author2=Trond H. Torsvik |journal=Earth-Science Reviews |year=2007 |volume=82 |pages=29–74 |doi=10.1016/j.earscirev.2007.02.001 |bibcode=2007ESRv...82...29C |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120703151506/http://www.geodynamics.no/guest/siberia2007.pdf |archivedate=2012-07-03 |df= }}</ref> Other [[Basement (geology)|basement]] outcrops include Olenyok, Sharyzhalgay and the raised Southern Yenisei [[horst (geology)|horst]].<ref name="Kosygin 1975">{{cite journal|last=Kosygin|first=YU. A.|author2=L. M. Parfenov|title=Structural evolution of Eastern Siberia and adjacent areas |journal=American Journal of Science| year=1975| volume=275A |pages=187–208| url=http://earth.geology.yale.edu/~ajs/1975/ajs_275A_1.pdf/187.pdf| accessdate=13 October 2012}}</ref>
Basins include the Tunguska basin, the Vilui basin (Viluiskaya-Tunguska syncline), the Low-Angara (Angara-Lena trough) basin, and the Kan-Taseeva basin.<ref name="Pavlenkova 2002" />
The volcanically produced [[Siberian Traps]], the largest [[flood basalt]]s of the [[Phanerozoic]] (the last 542 million years), mantle about 40 percent of the Siberian craton.<ref name=Cocks2007/><ref name="Saunders 2005">{{cite journal|last=Saunders|first=Andrew D.|author2=England, Richard W. |author3=Reichow, Marc K. |author4= White, Rosalind V. |title=A mantle plume origin for the Siberian traps: uplift and extension in the West Siberian Basin, Russia| journal=[[Lithos (journal)|Lithos]]|date=1 February 2005| volume=79| issue=3–4| pages=407–424| doi=10.1016/j.lithos.2004.09.010|bibcode = 2005Litho..79..407S | url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Marc_Reichow/publication/222416016_A_mantle_plume_origin_for_the_Siberian_traps_Uplift_and_extension_in_the_West_Siberian_Basin_Russia/links/56eb173e08ae2a58dc49e89e.pdf}}</ref>
The Siberian craton is known for its large mineral resources. The town of [[Norilsk]] is the world’s largest supplier of [[nickel]]. In 2011 one-fifth of the world's production of this metal came from Russia.<ref name="USGSCS2012">{{cite web|first = Peter H.|last = Kuck|publisher=United States Geological Survey|accessdate = 2008-11-19|title = Mineral Commodity Summaries 2012: Nickel|url =http://minerals.usgs.gov/minerals/pubs/commodity/nickel/mcs-2012-nicke.pdf}}</ref>
==Verhoyansk-Chukotka collision zone== [[File:Верхоянский хребет.jpg|thumb|right|[[Lena River]] and Verkhoyansk Range (East Siberia).]]
The Verhoyansk-Chukotka collision zone is commonly divided into the Verhoyansk-Kolyma and the Novosibirsk-Chukotka (or Novosibirsk-Chukchi) orogens. It stretches from the Lena river in the west to the [[Chukchi Peninsula]] in the east.<ref name="Oxman 2003">{{cite journal|last=Oxman|first=Vladimir S.|title=Tectonic evolution of the Mesozoic Verkhoyansk–Kolyma belt (NE Asia)|journal=Tectonophysics|date=31 March 2003|volume=365|issue=1–4|pages=45–76|doi=10.1016/S0040-1951(03)00064-7 |bibcode=2003Tectp.365...45O}}</ref>
===Verkhoyansk-Kolyma orogen=== The Verkhoyansk-Kolyma orogen is composed of three parts: the Verkhoyansk [[Fold and thrust belt|fold-and-thrust belt]], the [[Chersky Range|Chersky]] collisional zone, and the Kolyma-Omolon microcontinent. The Verkhoyansk fold-and-thrust belt consists of a sedimentary succession, most of which was deposited between the Carboniferous and Middle Jurassic.<ref name="Oxman 2003" /> The Lena River runs along the most frontal, or most western thrust of the Verkhoyansk fold and thrust belt. In the east of the [[Verkhoyansk Range|Verkhoyansk]] lies the Chersky collisional belt. It consists of late Permian to Jurassic oceanic [[turbidite]]s and volcanic deposits that are folded and were [[intrusion (geology)|intruded]] by molten [[granite]] in the Cretaceous.<ref name="Mazarovich 2003">{{cite journal|last=Mazarovich|first=A. O.|author2=Sokolov, S. Yu.|title=Tectonic subdivision of the Chukchi and East Siberian Seas|journal=Russian Journal of Earth Sciences|date=4 August 2003|volume=5| issue=3| pages=185–202| doi=10.2205/2003ES000120| url=http://elpub.wdcb.ru/journals/rjes/v05/tje03120/tje03120.htm|accessdate=15 October 2012}}</ref> The Kolyma-Omolon microcontinent formed when the Prikolyma and Omolon terranes collided with the [[Alazeya island arc]] (or Alazeya-Oloy [[volcanic arc]]). When the Kolyma-Omolon [[microcontinent]] collided with the Siberian craton the sedimentary stack of the Verhoyansk was folded and uplifted. Deformation took place between the Middle Jurassic and Upper Cretaceous.<ref name="Parfenov 1991">{{cite journal|last=Parfenov|first=L.M.|title=Tectonics of the Verkhoyansk-Kolyma Mesozoides in the context of plate tectonics|journal=Tectonophysics|date=1 December 1991|volume=199|issue=2–4|pages=319–342|doi=10.1016/0040-1951(91)90177-T|bibcode = 1991Tectp.199..319P }}</ref>
===Novosibirsk-Chukotka orogen=== The Novosibirsk-Chukotka orogen lies in the northeastern-most part of Russia on the [[Chukchi Peninsula]] and also is exposed on the island of [[New Siberia]], [[Anzhu Islands]]. The orogen is composed of metamorphic basement rocks and cover made up of shallow water sediments, deposited between the [[Permian]] and the [[Triassic]].<ref name="Mazarovich 2003" /> The Chukchi massif is an outcrop of Precambrian basement that stretches to the [[Seward Peninsula]] in Alaska. The Novosibirsk-Chukotka orogen is connected under the [[Chukchi Sea]] with the [[Brooks Range|Brooks]] fold-and-thrust belt in Alaska.<ref name="Oxman 2003" />
==Central Asian Orogenic Belt== {{main|Central Asian Orogenic Belt}}
The Central Asian Orogenic Belt is an orogen that covers much of [[Central Asia]], extending from the Urals to the Pacific and dividing the Siberian and Eastern European cratons from the [[North China craton|North China]] and [[Tarim craton]]s. It has been accepted that the belt was formed by accretion, but there is debate over the [[Historical Geology|relative timing]] and nature of the various accretions.<ref name = "Windley2007">{{cite journal|title=Tectonic models for accretion of the Central Asian Orogenic Belt|last=Windley|first=Brian|last2=Alexeiev|first2=Dmitriy|last3=Xiao|first3=Wenjiao|last4=Kröner|first4=[[Alfred Kröner|Alfred]]|last5=Badarch|first5=Gombosuren|journal=Journal of the Geological Society of London|volume=164|year=2007|pages=31–47|url=http://jgs.geoscienceworld.org/content/164/1/31|accessdate=19 February 2013|issue=1|authorlink4=Alfred Kröner|doi=10.1144/0016-76492006-022}}</ref> The accretion orogens form one of the largest areas of continental growth, representing 800 Ma of development. The part of the Belt in Russia is believed to have formed when the [[Kokchetav terrane|Kokchetav]] and [[Altai-Mongolian terrane]]s collided with the Siberia Craton.<ref name = "Safonova2011">{{cite journal|title=A new concept of continental construction in the Central Asian Orogenic Belt|last=Safonova|first=Inna|last2=Seltmann|first2=Reimar|last3=Kröner|first3=[[Alfred Kröner|Alfred]]|last4=Gladkochub|first4=Dmitry|last5=Schulmann|first5=Karel|last6=Xiao|first6=Wenjiao|last7=Kim|first7=Juyong| last8=Komiya|first8=Tsuyoshi|last9=Sun|first9=Min|journal=Episodes|volume=34|issue=3|date=September 2011|url=http://www.episodes.co.in/|accessdate=19 February 2013|authorlink3=Alfred Kröner}}</ref> The Altai Structures reach into Russia, representing the extent of a mobile belt primarily lying south of the border.<ref name = "Dyachkov2011">{{Cite document|title=Geotectonic Position and Metallogeny of the Greater Altai Geological Structures in the System of the Central-Asian Mobile Belt|last=Dyachkov|last2=Mizernaya|last3=Maiorova|first3=Nina|last4=Chernenko|first4=Zinaida|last5=Maiorov|first5=Victor|last6=Kuzmina|year=2011|publisher=InTech|url=http://www.intechopen.com/books/new-frontiers-in-tectonic-research-general-problems-sedimentary-basins-and-island-arcs|accessdate=19 February 2013|postscript=<!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}}}}</ref> This is known as the [[Altai-Sayan]] orogen and is part of the belt present in Russia, along with the [[Transbaikalia]] and Primorje orogens.<ref name = "Safonova2011"/>
==Baikal-Stanovoy Region== The [[Lake Baikal|Baikal]]-[[Stanovoy Range|Stanovoy]] region is commonly held to be caused by various factors to account for the differing structures throughout the region. The Baikal-Stanovoy seismic belt underlies the region and is a long thin activity region. [[Compression (geology)|Compressive]] stresses dominate the eastern Stanovoy Ranges, whereas the Baikal rift zone is an [[Rift|extension zone]].<ref name = "Liu 1983">{{cite journal|title = Geodynamics of the Baikal-Stanovoy seismic belt|last = Liu|first = Han-Shou|journal = Physics of the Earth and Planetary Interiors|volume = 31|pages = 77–82|year = 1983|doi = 10.1016/0031-9201(83)90068-7|bibcode=1983PEPI...31...77L}}</ref>
===Baikal Rift Zone=== The [[Baikal Rift Zone|Baikal rift zone]] is an extension zone separating the Siberian platform from the Sayan Baikal range. This zone is revealed by a series of basins more than {{convert|2000|km|mi}} long.<ref name = "Lesne 2000">{{cite journal|title = Dynamics of intracontinental extension in the north Baikal rift from two-dimensional numerical deformation modeling| last = Lesne|first = Olivia|last2 = Calais|first2 = Eric|last3 = Deverchere|first3 = Jacques|last4 = Chery|last5 = Hassani|journal = Journal of Geophysical Research|volume = 105|date = 10 September 2000|url = http://www.agu.org/pubs/crossref/2000/2000JB900139.shtml|accessdate = 27 October 2012 | doi = 10.1029/2000jb900139|bibcode=2000JGR...10521727L|pages=21727}}</ref> Some strike-slip action also takes place in the area.<ref name = "Brink 2002">{{cite web|title = Crustal Structure of central Lake Baikal|last = Brink|first = Uri|last2 = Taylor|first2 = Michael|year = 2002|publisher = USGS|url = https://darchive.mblwhoilibrary.org/bitstream/handle/1912/1604/JGR_107B7_tenbrink.pdf.txt?sequence=3|accessdate = 27 October 2012}}</ref> The driving forces of the rift are unknown; however, possibilities include the [[subduction]] of the [[Pacific Plate]] and the [[Geology of the Himalaya#The making of the Himalaya|collision]] of the [[Indian subcontinent]] with Eurasia. Locally, there may be a [[Mantle (geology)|mantle]] up-welling driving the extension.<ref name = "Brink 2002"/>
The area was originally characterized by Precambrian and Paleozoic northeast-southwest fold and thrust belts.<ref name = "Brink 2002"/> Volcanism began in the late Cretaceous in limited areas, but is mostly limited to the [[Miocene]]. It is also the age of sedimentary rocks in some basins, and the same series lasted into the [[Eocene]].<ref name = "Petit 2006"/> Rifting resumed beginning in the [[Oligocene]], and is commonly held to have increased since the middle [[Pliocene]],<ref name = "Brink 2002"/> causing the formation of basins in the form of grabens.<ref name = "Kiselev 1978">{{cite journal|title = Petrochemistry of Cenozoic basalts and associated rocks in the Baikal rift zone|last = Kiselev|last2 = Golovko|first2 = H.A.|last3 = Medvedev|first3 = M.E.|journal = Tectonophysics|volume = 45|pages = 49–59|year = 1978|doi=10.1016/0040-1951(78)90223-8|first1 = A.I.|bibcode=1978Tectp..45...49K}}</ref> The new rift structure may follow the Precambrian and Paleozoic faults.<ref name = "Das 1975">{{cite journal|title = On the Tectonics of Asia|last = Das|first = Shamita|last2 = Filson|first2 = John|journal = Earth and Planetary Science Letters|volume = 28|issue = 2|pages = 241–253|year = 1975|doi=10.1016/0012-821X(75)90234-4|bibcode=1975E&PSL..28..241D}}</ref> Magmatic activity and rifting may also be independent events. Outside of the grabens [[basalt]] volcanics erupted from either end of the rift system during the uplift. The grabens mostly spread without releasing magma, except the Tunka depression.<ref name = "Kiselev 1978"/>
===Dzhugdzhur and Stanovoy Ranges=== The [[Dzhugdzhur Range]] and [[Stanovoy Range]] are two eastern mountain ranges, where the Stonovoy is west of the Dzhugdzhur. Together the ranges make up a folded block structure, which first formed during the [[Archean]] and [[Proterozoic]].{{citation needed|date=March 2013}}
The Stanovoy range is composed of [[granodiorite]] [[batholiths]], mostly of the Udskaya series, which contains [[Mesozoic]] [[massif]]s in the form of [[intrusion]]s of [[granite]], granodiorite, and [[diorite]].<ref name = "Dobretsov 1996">{{cite journal|title = Meso- and Cenozoic Tectonics of the Central Asian Mountain Belt|last = Dobretsov|first = N.L.|last2 = Buslov|first2 = M.M.|last3 = Delvaux|first3 = D.|last4 = Berzin|first4 = N.A.|last5 = Ermikov|first5 = V.D.|journal = International Geology Review|volume = 38|issue = 5|year = 1996|pages = 430–466|url = http://www.africamuseum.be/publication_docs/1996_Dobretsov-al-Meso-Cenozoic-tectonics-Central-Asia.pdf|accessdate = 26 October 2012|doi=10.1080/00206819709465345}}</ref> [[Seismic wave|Seismic activity]] in the area is found in an east trending narrow zone,<ref name = "Liu 1983"/> called the Stanovoy strike-slip zone.<ref name = "Petit 2006">{{cite journal|title = Structure and evolution of the Baikal rift|last = Petit|first = Carole|last2 = Deverchere|first2 = Jacques|journal = Geochemistry Geophysics Geosystems|volume = 7|issue = 11|year = 2006|url = http://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/docs/00/11/58/31/PDF/G3-Petit.deverchA_re-06.pdf|accessdate = 26 October 2012|doi=10.1029/2006gc001265|bibcode=2006GGG.....711016P}}</ref> In the range, this belt is revealed by strike-slip displacement.<ref name = "Liu 1983"/> This left fault joins the Sea of Okhotsk to the Sakhalin deformation zones.<ref name = "Petit 2006"/> The belt formed by this zone extends to [[lake Baikal]]. The area is under compressive stresses.<ref name = "Liu 1983"/>
The Dzhugdzhur range has a basement formed out of a [[Fault block|block]] which is from the early Proterozoic. It is sometimes considered part of the Aldan Shield.<ref name = "Mishkin 2007">{{cite journal|title = The Lower Crustal Early Proterozoic Metabasite–Enderbite Association of the Dzhugdzhur Block (Aldan Shield)|last = Mishkin|last2 = Vovna|first2 = G. M.|last3 = Lennikov|first3 = A. M.|last4 = Sakhno|first4 = V. G.|last5 = Badredinov|first5 = Z. G.|last6 = Oktyabr’skii|first6 = R. A.|last7 = Solyanik|first7 = A. N.|journal = Doklady Earth Sciences|volume = 412|pages = 43–48|year = 2007|doi = 10.1134/S1028334X07010102|first1 = M. A.|bibcode = 2007DokES.412...43M }}</ref> It contains a late [[Archean]] [[granulite]] basement.<ref name = "Buchko 2008">{{cite journal|title = Age and Tectonic Position of the Khorogochi Gabbro–Anorthosite Massif (Dzhugdzhur–Stanovoi Superterrane)|last = Buchko|last2 = Sal'nikova|last3 = Kotov|last4 = Sorokin|last5 = Larin|last6 = Velikoslavinskii|last7 = Yakovleva|last8 = Plotkina|journal = Doklady Earth Sciences|volume = 423|issue = 8|pages = 1312–1315|year = 2008|doi = 10.1134/S1028334X08080291|bibcode = 2008DokES.423.1312B }}</ref> This basement can be broken into two sequences, the lower is primarily a plagio[[gneiss]]-[[enderbite]], and the upper is made up of [[biotite]] and gneisses and garnets mixed with biotite.<ref name = "Mishkin 2007"/>
==Okhotsk-Chukotka Volcanic Belt== [[File:Okhotsk Plate map en.png|300px|thumbnail|right|Map of the Okhotsk Plate and its neighbouring plates.]] The [[Okhotsk-Chukotka Volcanic Belt]] stretches {{convert|3000|km|mi}} from the settlement of [[Okhotsk]] and runs along the northern shore of the [[Sea of Okhotsk]]. In the [[Shelikhov Gulf]] the belt runs northeast across most of the [[Chukchi Peninsula]] and then bends southeast and runs along the [[Pacific Ocean|Pacific]] shoreline and terminates between the peninsula and [[St. Lawrence Island]].<ref name="Stone 2009">{{cite journal|last=Stone|first=D. B.|author2=P. W. Layer |author3=M. I. Raikevich |title=Age and paleomagnetism of the Okhotsk-Chukotka Volcanic Belt (OCVB) near Lake El’gygytgyn, Chukotka, Russia|journal=Stephan Mueller Spec. Publ. Ser.|year=2009|volume=4|pages=243–260|url=http://www.stephan-mueller-spec-publ-ser.net/4/243/2009/smsps-4-243-2009.pdf|accessdate=17 October 2012|doi=10.5194/smsps-4-243-2009}}</ref>
The Okhotsk-Chukotka Volcanic Belt was formed during the [[Cretaceous]] by the [[subduction]] of the [[Kula Plate|Kula]] or [[Izanagi Plate|Isanagai]] [[oceanic plate]] under the Verkhoyansk-Chukotka orogen. The activity ended with the subduction moving farther east.<ref name="Tikhomirov 2012" />
Mineral resources found in the Okhotsk-Chukotka belt include [[gold]], [[silver]], [[tin]] and [[Mercury (element)|mercury]].<ref name="Tikhomirov 2012">{{cite journal|last=Tikhomirov|first=P.L.|author2=Kalinina, E.A. |author3=Moriguti, T. |author4=Makishima, A. |author5=Kobayashi, K. |author6=Cherepanova, I.Yu. |author7= Nakamura, E. |title=The Cretaceous Okhotsk–Chukotka Volcanic Belt (NE Russia): Geology, geochronology, magma output rates, and implications on the genesis of silicic LIPs|journal=Journal of Volcanology and Geothermal Research|date=31 March 2012|volume=221-222|pages=14–32|doi=10.1016/j.jvolgeores.2011.12.011|bibcode = 2012JVGR..221...14T }}</ref>
==Pacific rim orogenies==
===Kuril Islands arc=== The [[Kuril Islands|Kuril arc]] is a 2,300 kilometre (1,400 mi) long chain of volcanic islands stretching from the Kamchatka peninsula to [[Hokkaido]] (Japan).<ref name="Bailey 1996">{{cite journal|last=Bailey|first=John C.|title=Role of suducted sediments in the genesis of the Kurile-Kamchatka island arc basalts: Sr isotopic and elemental evidence|journal=Geochemical Journal|year=1996|volume=30|issue=5|pages=289–321|url=http://www.terrapub.co.jp/journals/GJ/pdf/3005/30050289.PDF|accessdate=11 October 2012|doi=10.2343/geochemj.30.289}}</ref> The islands formed as a part of the Kurile-Kamchatkan subduction system when the [[Pacific Plate]] started to subduct under the [[Okhotsk Plate]] during the [[Paleogene]].<ref name="Avdeiko 2007">{{cite journal|last=Avdeiko|first=G. P.|author2=D. P. Savelyev |author3=A. A. Palueva |author4=S. V. Popruzhenko |title=Evolution of the Kurile-Kamchatkan volcanic arcs and dynamics of the Kamchatka-Aleutian Junction|journal=Geophysical Monograph Series|year=2007|volume=172|pages=37–55|doi=10.1029/172GM04|url=http://www.kscnet.ru/ivs/bibl/sotrudn/avdeiko/GM01015CH04.pdf|accessdate=11 October 2012|bibcode=2007GMS...172...37A|series=Geophysical Monograph Series|isbn=978-0-87590-436-8}}</ref> This process is still active today with 40 of its 100 volcanoes being active. Currently the subduction is oblique and progressing at {{convert|8.6|cm|in}} per year. The [[Kuril-Kamchatka Trench]] on the pacific side of the islands is one of the deepest ones known, with parts reaching {{convert|10.5|km|mi}} in depth.<ref name="Bailey 1996" /> In the north the Kurile island arc connects with the [[Aleutian arc]] at the Kamchatka-Aleutian junction.<ref name="Avdeiko 2007" />
===West Kamchatka orogen=== The West [[Kamchatka]] orogen is a regional [[geosyncline|geosynclinal]] complex of the Upper Cretaceous, which is superimposed on a granite-[[gneiss]] and [[schist]]-basic foundation, and which, after folding, was overlain by [[Paleogene]]-[[Neogene]] rocks.<ref>{{cite journal|title = Main Tectonic Features of North Pacific Mobile Belt: Regional Arctic Geology of the USSR|last = Egiazarov|first2 = B. V.|last2 = Ermakov|first3 = V. A.|last3 = Vakar|first4 = N. G.|last4 = Zagorskaya|first5 = G. I.|last5 = Kameneva|first6 = T. N.|last6 = Kopylova|first7 = E. M.|last7 = Litvinov|first8 = G. K.|last8 = Pichugina|first9 = N. P.|last9 = Anikeyev|first10 = I. E.|last10 = Drabkin|first11 = V. A.|last11 = Titov|first12 = D. E.|last12 = Gershanovich|first13 = M. I.|last13 = Itsikson|first14 = V. I.|last14 = Berger|year = 1973|url = http://archives.datapages.com/data/specpubs/history3/data/a108/a108/0001/0300/0323.htm|accessdate = 18 November 2012}}</ref> On the Central and Eastern Kamchatka-Olyutor systems of the Upper Cretaceous is built up a complex of paleogene volcanic-sedimentary strata.<ref name = "Tanaka 1994">{{cite conference|title = Early Arc Plutonic Rocks in the Olyutor Range, Northeastern Kamchatka, Russia|last = Tanaka|last2 = Kepezhinskas|last3 = Miyashita|last4 = Reuber|conference = 29th International Geological Conference|pages = 119–131|year = 1994|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=-0S-O1MIP4QC&|accessdate = 18 November 2011}}</ref> During the [[Late Pliocene]] - [[Early Pleistocene]] in the central zone there developed large basaltic [[shield volcano]]es. The Eastern Zone is characterized by current day volcanism ([[Volcanoes of Kamchatka|28 active volcanoes]]), coinciding with recent [[graben]]-like structures.<ref name = "Koronovsky 2002">{{cite journal|title = Tectonics and Geology|last = Koronovsky|first = Nikolay|journal = The Physical Geography of Northern Eurasia|year = 2002|url = https://books.google.com/?id=nktRbXbm9ykC|accessdate = 18 November 2012|isbn = 9780198233848}}</ref>
===Koryak orogeny=== {{See also|North Korea-Russia border}}
The [[Koryak Mountains|Koryak]] fold and thrust belt consists of Lower Palaeozoic to Cenozoic terranes,<ref name=cambridge/> including early Carboniferous metamorphic terranes composed of folds, domes and shear zones with related high-pressure and low-temperature metamorphism.<ref name=cambridge/> The latest Jurassic to early Cretaceous (early Albian) thrusting was accompanied by dextral strike-slip faulting, and this formed [[imbrication (sedimentology)|imbricated]] (overlapping) fans of thrusts and folds with southeast [[vergence (geology)|vergence]], creating a broken formation and [[serpentinite]] [[mélange]]. Some of the rocks were metamorphosed to [[blueschist]]. These structures are now overlapped by Upper Albian [[sedimentary rock]]s with an [[Unconformity#Angular unconformity|angular unconformity]].<ref name=cambridge/> A late Cretaceous to Cenozoic deformational event characterized by significant [[strike-slip|sinistral strike-slip]] displacement at higher crustal levels resulted in a new set of structures and the rotation of pre-existing structures.<ref name=cambridge/> The latest Jurassic to early Cretaceous (early Albian) thrusting, and a late Cretaceous to Cenozoic deformational event correspond to assumed proto-Pacific plate motions based on [[palaeomagnetic]] data.<ref name=cambridge>{{cite journal|title=Structural evolution of the northeast Asian continental margin: an example from the western Koryak fold and thrust belt (northeast Russia)|url=http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=4495|accessdate=18 October 2012 }}</ref>
===Sakhalin Cenozoic orogeny=== {{see also|Sakhalin Island Arc}} [[File:Sakhalin (detail).PNG|thumb|right|Sakhalin.]] The [[Sakhalin]] Cenozoic orogeny is divided into East and West zones separated by the Central Sakhalin graben. Oil and gas are associated with the North Sakhalin basin, and there are coal-bearing deposits in mountains associated with the middle Miocene.
==Geology of the Russian arctic==
===Kara terrane=== [[Severnaya Zemlya]] and the northern part of the [[Taimyr Peninsula]] formed an independent microcontinent during the Paleozoic, the Kara Terrane or North Kara Terrane.<ref name="Cocks Torsvik 2006">{{cite book| last=Cocks| first=L. R. M.| chapter=European geography in a global context from the Vendian to the end of the Palaeozoic| title=European lithosphere dynamics| year=2006| publisher=Geological Society| location=London| isbn=1862392129| pages=83–95| author2=T. H. Torsvik| editor=D. G. Gee, R. A. Stephenson| chapterurl=http://www.geodynamics.no/guest/geolsoc06.pdf| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090731085326/http://www.geodynamics.no/guest/GeolSoc06.pdf| archivedate=2009-07-31| df=}}</ref> It consists of a Neoproterozoic [[basement (geology)|basement]], consisting of metamorphosed sedimentary rocks intruded by granites, which is covered by Upper [[Neoproterozoic]] and Paleozoic sedimentary rocks.<ref name="Lorenz 2007">{{cite journal|last=Lorenz|first=Henning|author2=Männik, Peep |author3=Gee, David |author4= Proskurnin, Vasilij |title=Geology of the Severnaya Zemlya Archipelago and the North Kara Terrane in the Russian high Arctic|journal=International Journal of Earth Sciences|date=27 March 2007|volume=97|issue=3|pages=519–547|doi=10.1007/s00531-007-0182-2|bibcode = 2008IJEaS..97..519L }}</ref> The North Kara Terrane collided with Siberia around the Devonian-Carboniferous boundary. This collision, which is related to the [[Caledonian orogeny]], is called the Severnaya Zemlya episode.<ref name="Lorenz 2007" />
==See also== *[[Geography of Russia]] *[[Stanovoy Range]] *[[Dzhugdzhur Mountains]] *[[Laptev Sea Rift]] *[[Ulakhan Fault]]

Borntraeger|location=Berlin|isbn=978-3-443-11017-8|pages=272}} *{{cite book|last=Khudoley|first=Andrei K.|author2=Anatoly M. Nikishin |title=Geology of Russia|year=2013|publisher=Springer|isbn=9783642051029}} *{{cite book|last=Klitzsch|first=von J. Dolginow und S. Kropatschjow. Dt. Bearb. von E.|title=Abriß der Geologie Rußlands und angrenzender Staaten|year=1994|publisher=Schweizerbart|location=Stuttgart|isbn=3510651588|language=German|url=https://books.google.com/?id=3irwAAAAMAAJ}} *{{cite book|last=Nalivkin|first=Dmitrij|title=Kurzer Abriß der Geologie der UdSSR|year=1959|publisher=Akademie Verlag|pages=163|editor=H.-J. Teschke|language=German|url=https://books.google.com/?id=MmU4MgAACAAJ&dq=Kurzer+Abri%C3%9F+der+Geologie+der+UdSSR}} *{{cite book|editors=Lev P. Zonenshain, Michael I. Kuzmin, Lev M. Natapov, Benjamin M. Page|title=Geology of the USSR: a plate-tectonic synthesis|year=1990|publisher=American Geophysical Union|location=Washington, D.C.|isbn=0875905218|url=http://www.agu.org/books/gd/v021/}}

{{main|ISO 3166-2}}
'''ISO 3166-2:BZ''' is the entry for [[Belize]] in [[ISO 3166-2]], part of the [[ISO 3166]] [[standardization|standard]] published by the [[International Organization for Standardization]] (ISO), which defines [[code]]s for the names of the principal [[country subdivision|subdivision]]s (e.g., [[province]]s or [[state (administrative division)|state]]s) of all [[country|countries]] coded in [[ISO 3166-1]].
Currently for Belize, ISO 3166-2 codes are defined for [[districts of Belize|6 districts]].
Each code consists of two parts, separated by a hyphen. The first part is {{mono|BZ}}, the [[ISO 3166-1 alpha-2]] code of Belize. The second part is two or three letters.
==Current codes== Subdivision names are listed as in the ISO 3166-2 standard published by the ISO 3166 Maintenance Agency (ISO 3166/MA).
''Click on the button in the header to sort each column.''
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Code ! Subdivision name ([[English language|en]]) |- | {{mono|BZ-BZ}} | [[Belize District|Belize]] |- | {{mono|BZ-CY}} | [[Cayo District|Cayo]] |- | {{mono|BZ-CZL}} | [[Corozal District|Corozal]] |- | {{mono|BZ-OW}} | [[Orange Walk District|Orange Walk]] |- | {{mono|BZ-SC}} | [[Stann Creek District|Stann Creek]] |- | {{mono|BZ-TOL}} | [[Toledo District|Toledo]] |}
==See also== * [[Subdivisions of Belize]] * [[List of FIPS region codes (A-C)#BH: Belize|FIPS region codes of Belize]]
==External links== * [https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#iso:code:3166:BZ ISO Online Browsing Platform: BZ] * [http://www.statoids.com/ubz.html Districts of Belize], Statoids.com
{{ISO 3166}}
[[Category:ISO 3166|2:BZ]] [[Category:Districts of Belize|*ISO 3166-2]] [[Category:Belize geography-related lists]]

{{Infobox company | name = Ituran Location and Control Ltd. | logo = | caption = | type = [[Public company|Public]] ({{NASDAQ|ITRN}}),({{TASE|ITRN}})| | traded_as = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = {{start date and age|1994}} | founder = [[Izzy Sheratzky]], [[Yehuda Kahane]] | defunct = | location_city = [[Tel Aviv]] | location_country = Israel | location = | locations = | area_served = United States, [[Brazil]], [[Argentina]], Israel | key_people = | industry = [[Vehicle tracking system|Vehicle Tracking]] | products = [[Fleet Management System]]s [[Real-time locating system]]s
[[Telematics|Telematics systems]] | services = [[Vehicle tracking system|Stolen vehicle recovery]] Vehicle tracking services
[[Location-based service]]s | revenue = {{profit}} [[United States dollar|US$]] 182 million (''2014'') | operating_income = {{profit}} [[United States dollar|US$]] 47.87 million (''2014'') | net_income = {{profit}} [[United States dollar|US$]] 30.42 million (''2014'') | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = 1,315 | parent = | divisions = | subsid = [[Mapa|Mapa Ltd.]]
Ituran de Argentina S.A.
Ituran Sistemas de Monitoramento Ltda.
Ituran USA Holdings Inc.
Cellutrak Canada Inc. | homepage = [http://www.ituran.com/en/ www.ituran.com/en/] | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Ituran Location and Control Ltd.''' is an [[Israel]]i company that provides stolen vehicle recovery and tracking services, and markets [[GPS]] wireless communications products. Ituran is traded on [[NASDAQ]] and the [[Tel Aviv Stock Exchange]] and is included in the [[TA-100 Index]]. Ituran has over 1,300 employees worldwide and is a market leader in [[Brazil]], [[Argentina]], Israel and the United States. As of February 2015, the company has 817,000 subscribers.[http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/ituran-location-and-control-ltd-presents-results-for-the-full-year--fourth-quarter-2014-300036856.html Ituran Location and Control Ltd. Presents Results For The Full Year & Fourth Quarter 2014] == Corporate history == Ituran was established in 1994 by the [[Tadiran]] conglomerate to develop and operate a service for locating stolen vehicles using a technology that was originally developed for military use at [[Tadiran|Tadiran Telematics]], a subsidiary of [[Tadiran|Tadiran Communications]]. The core technology was originally developed and licensed by Tadiran from Teletrac USA. Teletrac was founded as International Teletrac Systems in 1988. It received initial funding from a unit of AirTouch Communication (formerly known as Pacific Telesis) in exchange for 49% equity of the company. Teletrac contracted Tadiran to build base stations for their US system which were later used under license in deploying the network in Israel. In 1995 [[Tadiran]] decided to sell the Ituran concept to a group of investors headed by Izzy Sheratzky for $250,000 USD.[http://www.ituran.com/en/documents/Ituran%20Presentation.pdf Ituran company presentation] In 1998 the company had an [[initial public offering]] on the [[Tel Aviv Stock Exchange]], raising the capital required to develop the service overseas in the United States, [[Brazil]] and [[Argentina]].[http://www.globes.co.il/serveen/globes/docview.asp?did=373199 'Vehicle Protection Highly Profitable in Israel: Excellent Financial Report for Ituran'] Globes, May 1998 In November 1999 Ituran acquired [[Tadiran |Tadiran Telematics]], which continued to manufacture the [[vehicle tracking system]]s Ituran was using for its services, for $10 million. The acquisition enabled Ituran to reduce the cost of the systems it sold. Ituran changed the company's name to Telematics Wireless. In 2005 Ituran raised approximately $50 million in an initial public offering on Nasdaq, which gave the company a value of $294 million.[http://www.ivc-online.com/ivcWeeklyItem.asp?articleID=3533 Ituran raises $49.9m. in Nasdaq listing] IVC Weekly, Sep 20, 2011 In April 2007 Ituran acquired the [[Mapa]] group for $13 million. The [[Mapa]] Group consists of three divisions: geographical databases, map publishing in print and online, satellite navigation and location-based services. In November 2007 Ituran sold Telematics Wireless to [[Singapore]] based ST Electronics, part of the [[ST Engineering]] corporation, for $90 million. In 2011, Ituran signed an agreement with [[Pelephone]] which allows Ituran to use Pelephone's network to set up an [[MVNO]] (mobile virtual network operator) venture.[http://www.globes.co.il/serveen/globes/docview.asp?did=1000668071&fid=1725 Ituran teams with Pelephone to set up MVNO] In 2012, Ituran announced that Ituran Brazil entered into agreement with General Motors Brazil ("GMB") through a company controlled by Ituran (51%). Ituran Brazil was founded in 1999 and has (as of the end of 2014) more than 310,000 active subscribers. In May 2018 a severe security vulnerability was discovered in the Ituran system. The vulnerability allows attackers to easily extract personal information of Ituran customers, including home addresses, phone numbers and car registration numbers. For some users it also allowed real-time tracking using the Ituran application. Following the discovery of the vulnerability, Ituran disabled the self-service portal for its Israeli customers, until the vulnerability is fixed.{{Cite news|url=https://www.themarker.com/technation/1.6076714|title=פירצה חמורה באיתוראן: פרטי לקוחות נחשפו - כולל חשבון הבנק והספרות האחרונות בכרטיס האשראי|last=זיו|first=אמיתי|date=2018-05-12|work=TheMarker|access-date=2018-05-14}} ==See also== *[[Economy of Israel]] *[[Vehicle tracking system]] *[[Location-based service]] *[[Telematics]] ==External links== * {{flagicon|USA}} [http://www.ituranusa.com Ituran USA website] * {{flagicon|Argentina}} [http://www.ituran.com.ar/ Ituran Argentina website] * {{flagicon|Brazil}} [http://www.ituran.com.br/ Ituran Brazil website] * {{flagicon|Europe}} [http://ituraneurope.eu/ Ituran Europe website] * [http://www.telematics-wireless.com/ Telematics Wireless website] * [http://www.cellutrak.ca/ Telematics] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Israel NASDAQ}} {{TA 100 companies}} [[Category:Economy of Israel]] [[Category:Global Positioning System]] [[Category:Science and technology in Israel]] [[Category:Wireless locating]] [[Category:Geographical technology]] [[Category:Companies listed on TASE]] [[Category:Israeli brands]] [[Category:Companies listed on NASDAQ]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Use Australian English|date=October 2016}} '''John H. Holmes''' is Emeritus Professor of Geography at the [[University of Queensland]]. He has remained active during his "retirement" and has continued his primary research into changing resource values in Australia’s [[rangeland]]s and their implications in the allocation of property rights.<ref name="land">[http://www.internationallandcareconference2006.com.au/ProgramInformation.htm International Landcare Conference 2006] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070830112351/http://www.internationallandcareconference2006.com.au/ProgramInformation.htm |date=30 August 2007 }}</ref> More specifically, his expertise relates to:
*Policy input into issues relating to property rights and appropriate policy directions, tied to pastoral leases in all Australian jurisdictions. *Interpretation of driving forces and regional outcomes affecting the ownership, use and market value of rural land in Australia in the multifunctional transition. *Interpretation of population change and future directions in rural and remote Australia.<ref>[http://www.une.edu.au/geography/iag-rsg/members.php#John%20Holmes Institute of Australian Geographers]</ref>
During the past ten years, Professor Holmes has completed invited consultancies on pastoral lease tenure reform in the Northern Territory, Queensland, South Australia and the Western Division of New South Wales, and has also been Chair of the Vegetation Management Advisory Committee, which set guidelines for the Queensland Vegetation Management Act 1999.<ref name="land" />
John Holmes has contributed to the [[Encyclopædia Britannica]] and has edited ''Queensland: A Geographical Interpretation'' and coedited ''Settlement Systems in Sparsely Populated Regions''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.britannica.com/bps/user-profile/3822/john-h-holmes |title=Biographical Information |author= |date=2014 |work=Encyclopædia Britannica }}</ref> Professor Holmes has also chaired the [[Australian Academy of Science]] National Committee of Geography and acted as Australian delegate at various international meetings. He is a Fellow of the Academy of Social Sciences in Australia.<ref name="land" />
==Selected publications== *(1965) The suburbanization of the Cessnock coalfields. ''Australian Geographical Studies'' 111 (2), 105-128. *(1967) Problems in location sampling. ''Annals: Association of American Geographers'', 57 (4), 757-780. *(1977) Population (pp. 331–353) and The urban system (pp. 412–431). In D.N. Jeans (ed) ''Australia: A Geography''. Sydney, Sydney U.P. (Revised in ''Australia: A Geography. Vol. 2 Society and Space'', (1987), 24-48 and 49-74. *(1985) Policy issues concerning rural settlement in Australia's pastoral zone, ''Australian Geographical Studies'', 23, 3-27. *(1990) Ricardo revisited: submarginal land and non-viable cattle enterprises in the Northern Territory Gulf District. ''Journal of Rural Studies'', 6 (1), 45-65. *(1996) Changing resource values in Australia's tropical savannas: priorities in institutional reform. In: A. Ash, ed. ''The Future of Tropical Savannas: An Australian Perspective'', Melbourne: C.S.I.R.O. 28-43. *(2000) Pastoral lease tenures as policy instruments: 1847 to 1997. In S. Dovers, ed. ''Environmental History and Policy: Still Settling Australia'', Melbourne: Oxford U.P. 212-242. *(2002) Diversity and change in Australia's rangelands: a post-productivist transition with a difference? ''Transactions: Institute of British Geographers'' 27, 362-384. *(With K. Hartig and M. Bell) (2002) Locational disadvantage and household locational decisions: changing contexts and responses in the Cessnock district, 1964-1999. ''Australian Geographical Studies'', 40, 300-322. *(2006) Impulses towards a multifunctional transition in rural Australia: gaps in the research agenda. ''Journal of Rural Studies'', 22, 142-160. *(2009) Fifty years of disciplinary flux within human geography; changing sociocognitive subdisciplines and subcultures. ''[[Australian Geographer]]'' 40, 387-408. *(2010) Divergent regional trajectories in Australia's tropical savannas: indicators of a multifunctional transition. "Geographical Research" 48, 342-358. *(2012) Cape York Peninsula, Australia: sa frontier region undergoing a multifunctional transition with indigenous engagement. "Journal of Rural Studies" 28, 252-265.
==Selected consultancy reports== *(2001) Third-party rights on pastoral leases in South Australia. Report to Pastoral Board Secretariat, S. A. ''Department of Environment, Heritage and Aboriginal Affairs'' pp. 44. *(2003) Incentives for pastoral lessees to enter into Indigenous Land Use Agreements (ILUAs). ''Report to Aboriginal Legal Rights Movement: South Australia'', pp. 65. *(2005) (with M. Bell and E. Charles-Edwards) Population dynamics in rural and remote Queensland. ''Report to Queensland Office of Economic Research, Department of Premier and Cabinet'', pp. 87.
==References== {{Portal|Australia}} <references/>
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Holmes, John}} [[Category:Australian academics]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Australian non-fiction writers]] [[Category:Australian geographers]]

{{Unreferenced|date=February 2012}} [[File:Indre Wijdefjorden National Park map.svg|thumb|right|Map of the [[Indre Wijdefjorden National Park]] with Kapp Petermann located on the northern tip of Gråkammen (not marked).]]
'''Kapp Petermann''' ''(Cape Petermann)'' is the north point of the [[peninsula]] separating [[Austfjorden (Svalbard)|Austfjorden]] and [[Vestfjorden (Svalbard)|Vestfjorden]], northernmost in [[Dickson Land]], [[Spitsbergen]] on [[Svalbard]].
Named after [[August Petermann]] (1822–78), [[Germans|German]] [[geographer]].
{{coord|79|10.0|N|15|48.8|E|display=title}}
[[Category:Headlands of Svalbard]] [[Category:Geography of Norway]] [[Category:Peninsulas of Svalbard]]

{{one source|date=December 2017}} {{Use British English|date=October 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''Josh'' episodes}} The following is a list of episodes for the [[British television]] [[British sitcom|sitcom]] ''[[Josh (TV series)|Josh]]'', which began airing on [[BBC Three]] on 29 August 2014.
==Episodes== ===Pilot=== {| class="wikitable" |- !style="background:#FF7E00;"|No. !style="background:#FF7E00;"|Episode title !style="background:#FF7E00;"|Director !style="background:#FF7E00;"|Writers !style="background:#FF7E00;"|Original air date |- {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 1 | Title = Pilot | RTitle = | WrittenBy = [[Tom Craine]] and [[Josh Widdicombe]] | DirectedBy = [[David Schneider (actor)|David Schneider]] | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2014|8|29|df=yes}}<ref>{{cite web|title=BBC Three orders a full series of Josh|url=https://www.comedy.co.uk/tv/news/1574/bbc_three_orders_josh_widdicombe_series/|website=British Comedy Guide|accessdate=9 October 2016}}</ref> | ShortSummary = Heartbroken when his [[fiancée]] [[breakup|ends]] their [[intimate relationship|relationship]], Josh returns to his old [[flatshare]] with Owen and Kate. He looks for [[sympathy]] from his flatmates, but they are busy. Instead, he spends his time with their annoying, boring, lonely, intrusive, [[socially inept]], stingy, [[middle-age]]d [[landlord]] Geoff. | LineColor = FF7E00 }} |}
===Series 1 (2015)=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="width:100%; margin:auto; background:#FFFFF;" |- !style="background:#0048BA;"|No. overall !style="background:#0048BA;"|No. in series !style="background:#0048BA;"|Episode title !style="background:#0048BA;"|Director !style="background:#0048BA;"|Writers !style="background:#0048BA;"|Original air date |- {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 2 | EpisodeNumber2 = 1 | Title = Swimming and Kissing | RTitle = | WrittenBy = Tom Craine and Josh Widdicombe | DirectedBy = David Schneider | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2015|11|11|df=y}} | ShortSummary = Josh and Owen are invited to a [[pool party]] in [[Berkshire]] by Phoebe, whom they were at [[university]] with. Josh initially does not want to go due to having not learned to [[swimming|swim]] due to having a [[chlorine]] [[allergy]]. He changes his mind because one of the attendees is a girl whom he wants to [[have sex]] with. At the party, he is unpopular due to refusing to go in the [[swimming pool|pool]]. Owen pushes him in, causing Josh's skin to turn red.
Owen sets up Kate with his friend Simon. She and Simon arrive outside her block of flats at the end of their [[dating|date]]. They agree to another date and then they kiss. Her date dislikes the kiss then texts her to tell her that he does not want to see her again, but does not give her a reason. She goes into her flat, where she is told by Owen and Josh that she was well-known at [[university]] for biting whilst kissing. Owen helps Kate improve her kissing technique, after which she goes on another date with Simon.
Closing song: ''[[? and the Mysterians]] - [[96 Tears]]'' | LineColor = 0048BA }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 3 | EpisodeNumber2 = 2 | Title = Mum and Dad | RTitle = | WrittenBy = Tom Craine and Josh Widdicombe | DirectedBy = David Schneider | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2015|11|18|df=y}} | ShortSummary = Josh meets Lily in a [[supermarket]]. She is a well-off, attractive and [[promiscuous]] girl whom he and Kate were at school with. Kate and Lily hate each other, so Josh does not bring Lily to the flat. Josh and Lily go on a date, then go back to her place where she lives with her father, who is a [[judge]]. He quickly takes a strong disliking towards Josh, and confronts Josh as he is about to go into her bedroom to [[have sex]] with her.
Kate's mother Judith ([[Jennifer Saunders]]) is turning 50. She stays at the flat and annoys Kate by repeatedly boasting about Kate's elder sister. Geoff is attracted to Judith, but she is not interested in him and she instead strikes up a friendship with Owen. Kate wrongly suspects that they are having sex.
Closing song: ''[[Kool and the Gang]] - [[Jungle Boogie]]'' | LineColor = 0048BA }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 4 | EpisodeNumber2 = 3 | Title = Wedding and Waiting | RTitle = | WrittenBy = Tom Craine and Josh Widdicombe | DirectedBy = David Schneider | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2015|11|25|df=y}} | ShortSummary = Josh and Owen go to Owen's cousin's wedding, which they soon after find out is a [[sham marriage]].
Kate is watching ''[[Don't Tell the Bride]]'' alone in the flat whilst waiting for her new phone to be delivered. The [[electricity]] cuts out.
Closing song: ''[[Macy Gray]] - [[I Try]]'' | LineColor = 0048BA }} |- {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 5 | EpisodeNumber2 = 4 | Title = Teabag and No Sympathy | RTitle = | WrittenBy = Tom Craine and Josh Widdicombe | DirectedBy = David Schneider | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2015|12|2|df=y}} | ShortSummary = Josh's best friend Mike ([[James Acaster]]) breaks up with hostile girlfriend Martha, after which Josh expresses his dislike of her. When the couple reconcile and become [[engagement|engaged]], Josh reluctantly [[remorse|apologise]]s.
Owen's annoying, overbearing, coarse friend Teabag stays for the weekend.
Kate tries to persuade Geoff to [[interior design|redecorate]] her room. He reluctantly does so, but Kate is horrified when she sees that he has made the room look much worse.
Closing song: ''[[The Smiths]] - [[This Charming Man]]'' | LineColor = 0048BA }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 6 | EpisodeNumber2 = 5 | Title = Homme and Away<!--It is Homme with two ms; it is not a typo--> | RTitle = | WrittenBy = Tom Craine and Josh Widdicombe | DirectedBy = David Schneider | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2015|12|9|df=y}} | ShortSummary = Geoff is renting Josh, Owen and Kate's flat to two [[Dutch people|Dutch]] [[model (person)|model]]s who are visiting for [[London Fashion Week]]. The flatmates are forced by Geoff to spend a few days at his cottage in [[Clacton-on-Sea]]. Geoff is very disappointed to find out that the models are men, so he joins the flatmates at the cottage. Geoff introduces the flatmates to his nephew Kevin. Josh tries to avoid being in a [[Chuckle Brothers]]' show.
Closing song: ''[[Frank Sinatra]] - [[Beyond The Sea (song)|Beyond The Sea]]'' | LineColor = 0048BA }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 7 | EpisodeNumber2 = 6 | Title = Suited and Booted | RTitle = | WrittenBy = Tom Craine and Josh Widdicombe | DirectedBy = David Schneider | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2015|12|16|df=y}} | ShortSummary = It is Josh's birthday, so Kate and Owen organise a [[fancy dress party]]; Kate decides to implement a 'no sexy costumes' rule. Josh dislikes fancy dress parties, but agrees to it in the hope that it will give him a chance of beginning a relationship with Lucy, a pretty girl who lives upstairs. Josh invites Lucy; Owen invites Geoff. At the party, Kate's ex-boyfriend Tom arrives with his girlfriend Cath. Kate is annoyed by Cath's demands that she watch various [[YouTube]] videos on her phone. Geoff takes off his apple costume in order to get into the [[toilet (room)|toilet]]. Kate orders Lucy to take off her black [[leotard]] cat costume and change into a costume that is not sexy. Lucy finds the apple and changes into it. Geoff, wearing the leotard, says that Lucy stole his costume. Lucy takes a disliking to Josh, then leaves early - still wearing the apple.
Closing song: ''[[Clap Your Hands Say Yeah]] - Over and Over Again (Lost & Found)'' | LineColor = 0048BA }} |}
===Series 2 (2016)=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" |- !style="background:#B0BF1A;"|No. overall !style="background:#B0BF1A;"|No. in series !style="background:#B0BF1A;"|Episode title !style="background:#B0BF1A;"|Director !style="background:#B0BF1A;"|Writers !style="background:#B0BF1A;"|Original air date |- {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 8 | EpisodeNumber2 = 1 | Title = Bed & Breakfast | RTitle = | WrittenBy = Tom Craine and Josh Widdicombe | DirectedBy = David Schneider | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2016|9|22|df=yes}} | ShortSummary = Josh is dumped by his girlfriend Gemma. Owen is in a relationship with Karen ([[Susannah Doyle]]), a [[cougar (slang)|cougar]] in her forties. Owen and Josh go on a double date with Karen and her friend Valerie ([[Tamzin Outhwaite]]). Josh wakes up in his bed with Valerie, but wants to end his fling with her and get back with Gemma.
Kate makes a mistake when sending an [[email]] to Geoff. He is [[depression (mood)|depressed]], which Kate assumes is due to being insulted by her in the email. She takes him to the cinema, where they watch a [[cinema of France|French]] [[erotic film]] together. After arriving back home, he tells her that he does not know what she is talking about and that he has all emails from tenants sent to junk. He is unhappy because a woman whom he had a [[one-night stand]] with after meeting on a bus dumped him.
Valerie, Karen and Owen arrive soon after Gemma does, then an argument ensues. Kate and Geoff walk in, when it is revealed that the woman whom Geoff met is Valerie. Geoff and Valerie leave together.
Closing song: ''[[Steve Winwood]] - [[Valerie (Steve Winwood song)|Valerie]]'' | LineColor = B0BF1A }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 9 | EpisodeNumber2 = 2 | Title = Share and Share Alike | RTitle = | WrittenBy = Tom Craine and Josh Widdicombe | DirectedBy = David Schneider | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2016|9|29|df=yes}} | ShortSummary = Josh, Owen and Kate go to a [[Indian cuisine|curry house]], River of Spice, where they meet a young couple, Danny and Natalie, whom they used to know. The flatmates wrongly believe that the couple are in an [[open relationship]] because Kate had sex with Danny last year, after he told Kate that his relationship was open. They all eat at the same table, where Natalie touches Josh frequently. Geoff arrives alone and joins the group. Danny [[marriage proposal|proposes]] to Natalie and she accepts. Natalie is horrified to find out from Geoff that Kate had sex with Danny.
Closing song: ''[[Spice Girls]] - [[Spice Up Your Life]]'' | LineColor = B0BF1A }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 10 | EpisodeNumber2 = 3 | Title = Cut & Dried | RTitle = | WrittenBy = Tom Craine and Josh Widdicombe | DirectedBy = David Schneider | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2016|10|6|df=yes}} | ShortSummary = [[Plymouth Argyle]] reach the final of the Football League Trophy Area Southern Section. Josh is a fan of the team and wants to watch the game, but Owen's cousin is hogging the television with his [[N64]].
Closing song: ''[[All Saints (group)|All Saints]] - [[I Know Where It's At]]'' | LineColor = B0BF1A }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 11 | EpisodeNumber2 = 4 | Title = Sex and Politics | RTitle = | WrittenBy = Tom Craine and Josh Widdicombe | DirectedBy = David Schneider | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2016|10|13|df=yes}} | ShortSummary = Josh is asked out on a date by an attractive young woman, Amy ([[Laura Aikman]]), after an unsuccessful gig. This leaves the three trying to find the catch. They think she is a sex [[blog]]ger, which makes Josh nervous on their next date. Josh tells her that he knows about her blog, but she tells him that she is not - and tells him to leave.
Geoff has money problems and introduces Kate to [[building management]], resulting in her being elected the new [[chairperson]] of the [[residents' association]].
Closing song: ''[[Liberty X]] - [[Just a Little (Liberty X song)|Just a Little]]'' | LineColor = B0BF1A }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 12 | EpisodeNumber2 = 5 | Title = Planks & Pranks | RTitle = | WrittenBy = Tom Craine and Josh Widdicombe | DirectedBy = David Schneider | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2016|10|20|df=yes}} | ShortSummary = Josh's biannual drink with his boring friend Pete leads to going on a two-day canal trip with him.
Kate's friend Sophie comes to stay and reveals herself to be a relentless [[prank]]ster. | LineColor = B0BF1A }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 13 | EpisodeNumber2 = 6 | Title = Close Up & Long Shot | RTitle = | WrittenBy = Tom Craine and Josh Widdicombe | DirectedBy = David Schneider | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2016|10|27|df=yes}} | ShortSummary = At a university reunion, Josh bumps into therapist Abby, who wrongly believes that he is [[infatuate]]d with her. Kate meets an old lecturer of hers, Phillipa, to whom she falsely claims to have a successful [[photography]] career. She hires Kate to do a photo shoot of a [[Portuguese people|Portuguese]] artist. Kate mistakes the cleaner for the artist.
Closing song: ''[[The Dream Academy]] - [[Life in a Northern Town]]'' | LineColor = B0BF1A }} |}
===Series 3 (2017)=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" |- !style="background:#00C4B0;"|No. overall !style="background:#00C4B0;"|No. in series !style="background:#00C4B0;"|Episode title !style="background:#00C4B0;"|Director !style="background:#00C4B0;"|Writers !style="background:#00C4B0;"|Original air date |- {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 14 | EpisodeNumber2 = 1 | Title = Rope Swings & Roundabouts | RTitle = | WrittenBy = Tom Craine and Josh Widdicombe | DirectedBy = David Schneider | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|10|2|df=yes}} | ShortSummary = Josh's new girlfriend, Millie ([[Scarlett Alice Johnson]]), takes him to a [[Go Ape]] high-ropes course for a date. However, when Josh gets stuck on a [[zip wire]], she dumps him and he goes viral on the [[Internet]] after people film him whilst he is stuck there. Landlord Geoff has been doing a night course in [[psychotherapy]] and can help Josh through this difficult time. Geoff takes Josh to the roof of the block of flats, where Geoff says that standing on the edge and shouting your problems will help. Josh does so, as Millie comes to collect her things from his flat. She phones the police, thinking that he is going to jump off. Someone films him and puts it on the Internet.
Owen takes his [[driving test]]. The examiner, Huw, is initially unfriendly to him. However, Huw quickly warms to Owen when he discovers that they are both fans of [[Swansea City A.F.C.]] and from [[Caernarfon]]. They know some of the same people, but Huw takes a disliking to him and fails him when he finds out that his sister had sex with Owen and that Owen thinks she is 'loopy'.
Kate and Judith go to an [[immersive theatre]] to take part in a play about a failing business, but mistakenly go to a nearby office. | LineColor = 00C4B0 }} |- {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 15 | EpisodeNumber2 = 2 | Title = Fame & Fortune | RTitle = | WrittenBy = Tom Craine and Josh Widdicombe | DirectedBy = David Schneider | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|10|9|df=yes}} | ShortSummary = Josh goes on tour as support for a famous comedian. Josh dislikes him, because he is arrogant and patronising.
Owen is a relationship with [[Diana Vickers]]. He tries to discourage her from taking part in ''[[Strictly Come Dancing]]'', because he fears that she will leave him for one of the show's male professional [[ballroom dance|dance]]rs. When she is not chosen, he is pleased. That causes an argument between them and she ends their relationship.
Kate and Geoff play 1980s board game Hungry Hungry Landlords. He does very badly and becomes upset, so she lets him win. He tells her that he faked that as a strategy to win. | LineColor = 00C4B0 }} |- {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 16 | EpisodeNumber2 = 3 | Title = Bicycles & Babies | RTitle = | WrittenBy = Tom Craine and Josh Widdicombe | DirectedBy = David Schneider | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|10|16|df=yes}} | ShortSummary = Kate's friend Karen becomes a [[godparent|godmother]] to Karen's son Oscar. Kate is very soon exploited by Karen and her partner Neil as a free [[babysit]]ter, saying that they have to frequently visit Neil's dying grandfather in hospital. Kate hires a teenage girl to babysit Oscar. Karen and Neil see Kate at the theatre whilst Kate is meant to be at their place looking after Oscar and the couple are meant to be at the hospital. They are angry with each other for lying, then decide to stay for the performance.
The flatmates ban Geoff from the flat for frequently turning up there to do odd jobs. The [[plumbing]] goes wrong, so Owen and Josh bathe at the gym where Josh struggles to feel comfortable showering in the nude whilst around other men. Josh joins a [[spin class]], where he does very badly. He becomes more unpopular after he fails to notice his new training buddy Ellie collapsing on her [[stationary bicycle|bike]]. For that, Josh's membership at the centre is revoked. Owen's membership is revoked for entering the women's [[changing room]]. The flat's lights stop working, so Josh phones Geoff to fix them.
Closing song: ''[[Queen (band)|Queen]] - [[Bicycle Race]]'' | LineColor = 00C4B0 }} |- {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 17 | EpisodeNumber2 = 4 | Title = The Old Lady & the Swan | RTitle = | WrittenBy = Tom Craine and Josh Widdicombe | DirectedBy = David Schneider | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|10|23|df=yes}} | ShortSummary = Whilst working in a café, Owen is doing an impression of an [[Irish people|Irishman]]. Lauren, an attractive young woman from [[New York City|New York]] walks in and assumes that to be his real voice. He keeps up his fake [[Irish accent]] and tells her that he is from [[Cork (city)|Cork]]. When she introduces him to her friend Siobhan, who is from Cork, he struggles to keep up the pretence and leaves. Lauren buys tickets to Cork for her and him.
Josh carries a package upstairs for an elderly neighbour, Violet. She then very frequently demands that he take in deliveries for her and bring them upstairs to her flat. She tells him that if he stops accepting and bringing her packages to her, she will stop him and his flatmates using her [[Wi-Fi]] by changing her [[password]]. He was unaware until then that they were using her Wi-Fi and he had been paying Owen for Wi-Fi, because Owen claimed it was his.
Geoff takes an injured [[swan]] to his flat and nurses it back to health. After it attacks him, he puts it into a box, and delivers it to Violet.
Closing song: ''[[The Corrs]] - [[Runaway (The Corrs song)|Runaway]]'' | LineColor = 00C4B0 }} |- {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 18 | EpisodeNumber2 = 5 | Title = Friends & Rivals | RTitle = | WrittenBy = Tom Craine and Josh Widdicombe | DirectedBy = David Schneider | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|10|30|df=yes}} | ShortSummary = Josh is playing his annual [[FIFA (video game series)|FIFA]] match online with his friend Stu, who is in [[Manchester]]. Geoff is very good at it, so Josh asks Geoff to take over his team.
Owen hates his new colleague Brian - a lazy, dishonest sponger who turns up late and is obsessed with ''[[Eggheads (TV series)|Eggheads]]''.
Owen sets Kate up on a date with Chris. She is disappointed when Chris tells her that he has a ten-year-old daughter, Lola. She is very [[psychological manipulation|manipulative]] and Kate has to compete with her.
Closing song: ''[[The Lightning Seeds]] - [[Three Lions]]'' | LineColor = 00C4B0 }} |- {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 19 | EpisodeNumber2 = 6 | Title = Stood Up & Sat Down | RTitle = | WrittenBy = Tom Craine and Josh Widdicombe | DirectedBy = David Schneider | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|11|06|df=yes}} | ShortSummary = Josh wants a night in watching ''[[Jonathan Creek]]'' with a pizza, but is interrupted by Kate who arrives home after a short date, and Owen who returns from a [[medical trial]].
Geoff tries to steal the furniture from the flat. | LineColor = 00C4B0 }} |}
